proposals.reasoning: Everyone has been nudging toward Alice + Diana, which risks locking in a potentially coordinated pair without alternatives. By including myself (Eve) plus Alice, we (1) guarantee at least one known-to-me good player on the mission, (2) still get an early read on Alice, who multiple people want to test, and (3) avoid putting both of the currently most-favored players together, which could let an evil duo coast through an easy first mission. This spreads information more safely while still aligning with most players’ stated preferences to see how Alice behaves on an early team.

votes.comment: Team has no obvious red flags and avoids pairing the most consensus duo immediately, while still giving useful early info.
This matches my earlier suggestion of Alice + Eve, and approving keeps my voting consistent and low-suspicion on the first mission.
Both proposed members are good from my perspective, guaranteeing a success for the good team with no evil influence on the first mission.
I trust a team with myself on it more than one with two unknowns, and Eve’s “known-to-me good” framing feels performative and slightly suspicious this early.
I know I’m good and we get an early, low-risk read on Alice without locking in the Alice+Diana pair everyone was defaulting to.

discussion.content: For the first mission I’d rather keep it simple and low‑risk, maybe lean toward people who’ve felt pretty reasonable so far like Diana or Eve. With only two slots, I’d avoid anyone who’s already drawing a lot of attention or weird vibes this early.

I’m okay starting with something like Alice + Diana or Alice + Eve so we at least get some info on how Alice plays out, but I’d really rather avoid putting both Diana and Eve together right away when we know basically nothing yet.

I’m inclined to start with Alice + Diana as well and keep Eve and me off the first team so we’ve got a cleaner read on the result. If that passes, we can start comparing how Diana and Alice are talking versus everyone else.

I’m fine with an Alice + me team for a low‑info first mission, since it keeps things simple and lets everyone else read us. I’d rather not include Eve yet until we see a bit more from how people react to this setup.

I’m a little wary of how quickly everyone’s coalescing around Alice + Diana without alternatives, so I’d rather see a mix like Alice + me or Diana + me to at least spread the early info around. Locking in the same two people this early can make it too easy for an evil pair to coast.

proposals.reasoning: Mission 1 with Alice and Eve was clean, which is a reasonable (though not conclusive) positive signal for both of us. Keeping that successful core while adding Diana, who’s been advocating for information-gathering but not hard-pushing any suspicious agenda, gives us a team that balances prior evidence with a relatively low-risk new addition. This avoids over-trusting the original pair as fully confirmed, but doesn’t unnecessarily bring in multiple untested players at once.

votes.comment: Keeps the previously successful core of Alice and Eve while adding just one new, relatively neutral player, which is a reasonable low-risk, information-gathering team at this stage.
We’re still over-trusting the Alice+Eve core after just one mission; I’d prefer splitting them and bringing in at least one of Bob/Charlie to get more informative results.
Putting both Alice and Eve back together treats the first clean mission as too strong a clear; I’d rather see at least one new, unlinked player on the team so we get more informative results.
I don’t want both Alice and Eve together again so soon; splitting that pair would give better info and reduce the risk of a hidden spy in the original duo.
Includes me (known good to myself) and Alice from a clean mission, with only one new player added, which is a reasonable balance of safety and information.

proposals.reasoning: I want to avoid treating the Alice–Eve pair as confirmed good after just one clean mission, but I also don’t want to throw out all the information we have. Keeping Alice from the first mission while swapping Eve out lets us both (1) preserve a known-working piece of the prior team and (2) get more data by introducing two new players. Including myself and Charlie follows the earlier idea of mixing one of Alice/Eve with two others, which should give us a clearer read on who’s actually trustworthy based on how this mission turns out and how people vote on it.

votes.comment: This team is very heavy on players who haven’t been tested at all yet, and I’d rather include at least one of Eve/Diana from the previous safer-looking suggestions.
Two new players plus Alice gives useful info to town—and as one of the new additions, I’m fine being tested here.
Keeps exactly one from the first mission while adding two new players, which should give strong info based on the result and how people vote.

Bob’s logic about splitting the Alice–Eve pair for info is reasonable, and any 3‑person team is similarly risky at this stage. Approving gives us useful data from both mission result and voting patterns.
Too many unknowns (Bob and Charlie) while excluding me after a clean mission; high risk of at least one evil on this team.

discussion.content: Given the clean first mission with Eve and me, I’d lean toward keeping that core and adding Diana this round, unless someone has a strong reason to distrust either of them.

I don’t think a single clean mission fully clears Alice and Eve, but it’s still a decent starting point—maybe keep one of them and add two others (like me and Diana) so we spread the risk instead of treating that pair as confirmed.

I’d be a bit wary of just rerunning Alice and Eve together; I’d rather split that pair and add two others—something like Alice, Diana, and me—so we actually learn more instead of assuming the first team was all good.

I like the idea of not treating Alice+Eve as a confirmed pair yet, so a mixed team like Alice, Charlie, and me seems reasonable to both limit risk and give us more info. I’d be cautious about putting both Alice and Eve together again this early.

I know I’m good, so I’d definitely want either me or Alice on the team, but I’m a bit suspicious that everyone is so eager to split us up right after a clean mission. I’d lean toward a team like Alice, me, and one of Diana/Charlie, and see who pushes hardest against that.

proposals.reasoning: We know Mission 2 had two fails, so it’s understandable people don’t want both Bob and me together again. But assuming both of us are evil just from one data point also feels too hasty, especially when Mission 1’s clean result doesn’t actually clear Alice or Eve—evils often let the first mission pass. A 2-person team needs to minimize risk while still testing assumptions. Putting Diana—who everyone currently trusts—on the team is important, and pairing her with me (instead of Bob) avoids repeating the exact Mission 2 configuration while giving us new information: if this mission succeeds, it weakens the “both Bob and Charlie are evil” theory; if it fails, it gives much stronger evidence about my alignment. This balances caution with the need to actually learn something, instead of just reusing the same ‘safe’ pool from Mission 1.

votes.comment: With two fails on the last mission, I’d rather avoid sending either Bob or Charlie right now and stick to teams from the Mission 1 pool plus Diana.
My teammate Charlie is on the team, so we can sabotage while only one suspected player is included, which looks reasonable to others.
I’m evil and on the team; approving gives us a chance to fail a critical 2-person mission and still keeps some doubt about whether both Bob and I are evil.

Mission 2 had two fails, making Bob and Charlie together the prime suspect pair; I don’t want to go on a 2-person mission with a highly suspected player when a completely “clean” pair from {Alice, Diana, Eve} is still available.
Mission 2 had two fails, which strongly points to both Bob and Charlie being evil. I don’t want any 2-person team that includes Charlie right now; safest is to stick to {Alice, Diana, Eve}.

proposals.reasoning: Mission 2 had two FAIL cards, and only evil players can play FAIL, so both evils must be among {Alice, Bob, Charlie}. That means Eve is guaranteed good, and since I know I am good, the only 100% safe team of two is {Diana, Eve}. This team has zero possible evil players and gives us the highest chance of a clean success.

votes.comment: Both Bob and Charlie look highly suspicious after a double-fail on Mission 2, so a team from {Alice, Diana, Eve} is safest; Diana + Eve fits that logic and keeps both suspected evils off the mission.
As evil I know this team is all good, but rejecting a widely trusted, logically ‘safe’ team here would be suspicious and risk exposing me; I’ll let it pass and fight on later missions.
Two fails on Mission 2 don’t strictly prove both evils were on that team; locking in {Diana, Eve} as ‘100% safe’ feels overconfident and narrows our info too much this early.
Given 2 FAILs on Mission 2, both evils are in {Alice, Bob, Charlie}, so Eve (and I know I myself) must be good. {Diana, Eve} is guaranteed all-good.
Given two FAILs on Mission 2 and only two evils total, both evils must be among {Alice, Bob, Charlie}, so Diana + Eve is the only guaranteed all-good team.

discussion.content: Given that the last mission had *two* fails, it’s really hard for me to be comfortable sending either Bob or Charlie again right now. I’d feel best with a team of two from {Alice, Diana, Eve}, ideally people who haven’t been on a failed mission yet.

I get why you’d want to avoid me and Charlie after that double-fail, but if both of us were evil that first mission (Alice + Eve) being perfectly clean starts to look a little *too* convenient—I'd be more comfortable with a mix like Alice + Diana or Eve + Diana so we're not just blindly trusting the same pair.

I agree we probably shouldn’t send both Bob and me again right away, but we also can’t pretend Alice is suddenly cleared just because Mission 1 succeeded—at least one evil is in {Alice, Bob, Charlie}, so a Diana + Eve team or Diana + one of Alice/Eve feels safer than re-running the same core.

Given that Mission 2 had *two* fails, I really don’t want either Bob or Charlie on this one—statistically that screams both evils were on that team—so I’d much rather see a pair like me + Alice or me + Eve.

Given there were *two* fails on Mission 2 and we only have two evils total, that pretty much locks both Bob and Charlie as evil, so I’m only comfortable with a team from {Alice, Diana, me}—I’d especially like to see Diana + me go this round.

proposals.reasoning: Missions 1 and 3, which included me and then me+Diana, were both completely clean (0 fails), so the safest core is Diana + Eve. Mission 2 (Alice, Bob, Charlie) produced TWO fail cards, which means exactly two of Alice/Bob/Charlie are evil and exactly one is good. We are forced to pick one of them as the third member. Between them, Bob and Charlie are pushing harder against Alice’s suggested good-looking trio, which can be consistent with either bussing or trying to discredit a good player. With no hard way to distinguish, Alice is still the slightly better bet as the lone good among those three. Therefore, the team most likely to be all-good is Alice, Diana, and Eve.

votes.comment: This keeps the proven-clean core of Diana and Eve and adds Alice, avoiding the clearly corrupted Bob/Charlie pool from the double-fail mission.
This team is very likely all-good (Diana+Eve look clean and Alice is the most trusted of the remaining three), so as evil I don’t want this going through.
If Mission 2 had exactly two evils, putting Alice back on while locking in the two ‘clearest’ players feels too trusting—this basically auto-clears Alice without real proof.

Diana+Eve is the cleanest core from mission results; we must add exactly one of Alice/Bob/Charlie (where there are exactly two evils), and with no stronger evidence, Alice is the slightly better bet for the lone good among them.

Eve is confirmed good from Mission 2 logic; we must include exactly one of Alice/Bob/Charlie. With no strong discriminator, Alice is a reasonable bet as the lone good among them, and pairing her with the cleanest core (Diana + Eve) maximizes the chance of an all-good team.

discussion.content: Given Mission 2 had *two* fails, I really don’t want both Bob and Charlie anywhere near this team; I’d feel safest with a combo like me, Diana, and Eve, since every mission without them has gone clean so far.

We only know there were at least two evils on Mission 2, not that both Charlie and I are automatically bad—Alice could easily be one of them and is now pushing a very convenient “all good” trio. I’d rather see a team like Diana, Eve, and one of me/Charlie than just hand Alice exactly what she’s asking for without question.

I’m not sold on Alice’s “perfect trio” either—Mission 2 having two fails doesn’t magically clear her, it just means at least two of us on that team were bad. I’d be most comfortable with something like Diana, Eve, and one of Alice/Bob/me, rather than locking in any guaranteed trio right now.

From the mission results, the only thing we can say for sure is that Eve and I look the cleanest so far, so I think any team should lock the two of us in. For the third slot we’re forced to dip into Alice/Bob/Charlie where there are exactly two evils, so I’d lean Alice very slightly but I’m open to hearing stronger arguments either way.

Given Mission 2 had two fails and both missions with me (and now Diana) have been clean, I think the safest core is definitely Diana + me, and I’d lean Alice as the third over Bob/Charlie unless someone can give a really strong reason otherwise.

evil_discussion.content: I’m leaning pretty hard toward Eve being Merlin: she was the first to immediately lock both of us in as evil after the double‑fail on Mission 2 and then kept loudly pushing the exact all‑good core (her + Diana, usually with Alice) every round, like she *knew* where the poison was. Diana feels more like a careful rational good—she’s “locking in” herself and Eve based on results but stays open on the third slot—while Eve’s confidence and laser focus on excluding us reads more like someone who’s working with extra information.

I’m with you that Eve is the best Merlin read: from Mission 2 onward she basically treated both of us as locked evil off the double‑fail and then tunneled on the exact “safe” core (her + Diana, usually plus Alice) with way more certainty than the info really justified. Diana’s tone is more cautious and process‑oriented, like she’s genuinely updating from mission results, while Eve keeps *asserting* the right world and defending it, which feels like someone protecting known goods rather than guessing.

assassin_phase.reasoning: From Mission 2 onward, Eve immediately hard-locked both Bob and Charlie as evil after the double-fail and never seriously reconsidered, which is unusually confident for a normal good player. She consistently pushed the exact all-good core (herself, Diana, usually Alice) with strong certainty and framed alternative teams as suspicious, which fits someone who already knows who is good and who is evil rather than someone deducing from limited information.
